Former Supreme Court Chief Justice
Warren told a Shriver Hall audience Friday that the
Clogged court system is a large factor in the
nation's rising crime problem.
Speaking to an overflow crowd, Warren condemned the "law-and-order" rhetoric of the recent
campaign and the administration's failure to follow
the advice of recent commissions on crime and
violence.
Warren, who also served as Attorney General and
Governor of California, called for great infusions of
Personnel into the judicial system to help alleviate
court backlogs.
He pointed out that the cost of operating the
federal judicial system last year was less than half
the cost of a modern Navy cruiser.
The former Chief Justice argued that in the rush
to accuse each other of being "soft on crime,"
candidates neglected to discuss remedies for the
problem.
"As a result (of the accusations) the entire
campaign was one of harsh rhetoric and a search
for scapegoats responsible for the situation."
Among the neglected reports cited by Warren
were the Kerner commission report and the report
of the Commission on the causes of Violence,
chaired by former Hopkins President Milton S.
Eisenhower.
Warren praised the Commission's objectivity and
diligence, and condemned the reports' relegation to
a "status of "innocuous desuetude."

Henry Steele Comtnager

Historian Henry Steele Commager, speaking
before an enthusiastic crowd Thursday, asserted
that the worst violence in the country is now
committed against blacks and youth.
"In America, violence is clad in the vestments of
respectability and armored with the authority of
the law," he declared, noting that the government,
the military, and the police are the chief vessels of
"respectable" violence.
The American myth of natural superiority and
uniqueness, Commager charged, has formed and
sustains a double standard.
"The real violence," asserted Commager,"is the
violence of imposing inferiority on fellow men, the
viorence of poverty and ignorance and social
contempt."
Commager, a professor of American History at
Amherst College, said that America's original
violence was against the Indian, but it quickly
expanded to blacks.
"It is the ostentatious expressions of violence that
have always aroused our indignation—the violence
depicted by "Uncle Tom's Cabin," the violence of
5,000 lynchings in the South between 1882 and the
1920's, the race riots."
In much the same way that violence came
against blacks, Commager explained, it is now
aimed at American youth.
"American society looks upon the young with
suspicion, malice and envy, and equates a college
degree with a criminal record," he claimed.
Commager charged the American government
with a final violence of war. "Our Indian wars were
unnecessary and were conducted with an excess of
violence and barbarism. The Mexican war was
unnecessary. The Filipino war was all but inexcusable and was attended by the use of concentration camps and torture which has attended
our war in Viet Nam."
"It is not feasible to indulge lawlessness and
violence in one realm of society and government
and decry it in others," declared Commager. "The
war in Viet Nam is a war which, to save our own
souls, we must lose."

viorence of poverty and ignorance and social
contempt."

violence was against the Indian, but it quickly
expanded to blacks.

have always aroused our indignation—the violence
depicted by "Uncle Tom's Cabin," the violence of
5,000 lynchings in the South between 1882 and the
1920's, the race riots."

against blacks, Commager explained, it is now
aimed at American youth.

suspicion, malice and envy, and equates a college
degree with a criminal record," he claimed.

unnecessary. The Filipino war was all but inexcusable and was attended by the use of concentration camps and torture which has attended
